Proposition 16.  Le^ Ü be a well centred family of finite character defining the ring A
and such that the map Ф from fractionary ideals is onto ^.  Then A is a v - miiltiplication ring. 
Proof.  Let ( ^1 a „ ) be any finitely generated ideal ; let ( x^ = — mm го { а^ ).  Then
since ( л^ ),  ^£ ; Q IS compatible,  almost always zero,  and Ф is onto,  there exists a fractionary ideal M such that M { w ) = л^,  for each w^Q Let b^ M and let [ w - ^ • • • w^ be the finite set 0Î w ^Q such that w { b ) > oc^ ; then since Ф is onto,  for each t,  1 ^ ^ ^ ^,  there exists b^^M such that w^ ( bJ=oc^ Set N = - ( b^b^, . . ,  bj ; then iV ( ^ / ; ) = ^^ and ( iV ( ai • ( in ) ) iü = ^w — ^w " = 0 - Thus the c - ideal ( a^ • • • a^ ) ^ has the inverse iV^ which is finitely generated as a c - ideal,  1.  e the finitely generated c - ideals form a group.  It follows that the finite f - ideals are identical to the finite c - ideals. 
By Theorem 7 of [ 2 ] we may conclude that A is a ring of Krull type and consequently that the following statements about a ring A defined by a family of finite character are equivalent. 
( A ) A is defined by essential valuations. 
( B ) A IS defined by a weakly independent well centred family
( C ) The weak approximation theorem holds. 
( D ) The approximation theorem holds. 
( E ) A IS defined by well centred valuations,  and Ф maps the non zero fractionary ideals onto ^. 
Since the c - ideals have finite character we see that the c - ideals are identical to the ^ldeals for a ring of Krull type.  Thus Proposition 14 and Theorem 15 give the structure of the ^ldeals for a ring of Krull type
